text.p: Let [mathjaxinline]v_1 = \left[\begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 3 \\ 4 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]v_2 = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ -1 \\ 0 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline] be vectors in [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^3[/mathjaxinline].
Can you write [mathjaxinline]v_2[/mathjaxinline] as a linear combination of [mathjaxinline]v_1[/mathjaxinline]?

font.p:
A "yes" answer here would imply that some scalar, multiplied by [mathjaxinline]v_1[/mathjaxinline], equals [mathjaxinline]v_2[/mathjaxinline]. If [mathjaxinline]c \cdot v_1 = v_2[/mathjaxinline], then each entry of [mathjaxinline]v_1[/mathjaxinline], times [mathjaxinline]c[/mathjaxinline], equals its respective entry in [mathjaxinline]v_2[/mathjaxinline]:
[mathjaxinline]c \cdot 2 = 1[/mathjaxinline], [mathjaxinline]c \cdot 3 = -1[/mathjaxinline], and [mathjaxinline]c \cdot 4 = 0[/mathjaxinline].
We can see that this is inconsistent; for example, the third equation implies [mathjaxinline]c = 0[/mathjaxinline], and yet that would not satisfy the first or second equation.
